awd_abstract_narration:
Gamma-rays are the highest energy form of electromagnetic radiation.  Observations of astrophysical gamma-rays serve as probes of physical conditions and processes in the most extreme environments throughout the Universe, and can be used to test fundamental physics. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), located in southern Arizona, is designed to perform high-sensitivity pointed observations of both galactic and extragalactic sources.  This award supports scientists at the University of Iowa in their work on VERITAS.  The group will contribute to operations of the observatory and conduct scientific analysis of data from highly-energetic galactic gamma-ray sources.  They will also lead an effort to establish a long-term accessible archive of the VERITAS data.  Each summer, the group will host an undergraduate summer intern from an underrepresented minority group through the University of Iowa Summer Research Opportunities Program.

The University of Iowa group will use VERITAS to study very high energy galactic particle accelerators to probe their acceleration mechanisms.  They will observe with VERITAS the new pulsar wind nebulae and extended shell-type supernova remnants originally detected by complementary gamma-ray survey observatories.  They will continue to operate and maintain the VERITAS pointing monitors and to contribute to array operations.  The group will also lead a new effort to archive the high-level science results from VERITAS within the NASA HEARSAC system.

por.por_cntn:
The universe contains astrophysical objects that accelerate particles to energies beyond the reach of any accelerator yet built by humans.  What drives these accelerators is a major question in astrophysics.  Gamma-ray emission at very high energies in the teraelectron volt (TeV) range is a key diagnostic of highly energetic particles. The most sensitive TeV instruments are imaging air Cherenkov telescopes (IACTs) that use large optical reflectors on the ground to image the visible/UV light produced as Cherenkov radiation from energetic particles in air showers generated by gamma-rays interacting in the atmosphere.  We used the Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS) to study very high energy particle accelerators in our Milky Way galaxy. VERITAS is located near Tucson, Arizona, and is the only US-led IACT. We observed candidate objects that may accelerate particles to peva-electron-volt energies (called "Pevatrons") to better understand the origins of the populations of energetic particles within the galaxy. Some of these objects are sources newly discovered by the High Altitude Water Cherenkov observatory (HAWC). We created a publicly available archive of high-level science results from VERITAS that will enable other scientists to use VERITAS results in their own scientific studies. We continued to operate and maintain the VERITAS pointing monitors and contributed to array operations.

In addition to deepening our understanding of how energetic particles are accelerated and how they are distributed in our Milky Way galaxy, we also implemented a program to increase the participation of underrepresented minorities in astrophysics research, with an emphasis on first generation students. We hosted at the University of Iowa an undergraduate summer intern from an underrepresented minority. The students were enrolled in Iowa's Summer Research Opportunities Program (SROP) that includes professional development and social activities in addition to the research. One of the students subsequently participated in a NASA internship program, one published a Research Note with the American Astronomical Society, and several have taken up positions in industry.
